metadata.case_name: University of Delhi & Anr. v. Ram Nath & Anr.

facts.text: Ram Nath employed as driver by appellant No. 2 (Principal, Miranda House) in October 1949.
Ram Nath served notice on May 1, 1961 that services no longer required, discharged on payment of one month's salary in lieu of notice.
Asgar Masih employed initially by appellant No. 1 (University of Delhi) as driver, transferred to appellant No. 2 on October 1, 1949.
Asgar Masih's services terminated by notice on May 1, 1961 on payment of one month's salary in advance in lieu of notice.
Appellant No. 1 discontinued running buses for convenience of girl students attending college run by appellant No. 2 due to loss.
Retrenchment of the two drivers inevitable and genuine, no element of mala fides or unfair labour practice.
If employees are workmen and work is industry under s.2(j), s.25F not complied with and retrenchment compensation not paid.
Respondents filed petitions under s.33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act against appellants.

Labour Court, Delhi rejected preliminary objection that appellant No.1 not employer under s.2(g) and work not industry under s.2(j), ordered payment of Rs.10,50/- to each respondent as retrenchment compensation on September 22, 1961.
University of Delhi established under Delhi University Act, 1922 as teaching and affiliating University.
Organization of University consists of officers and authorities composed of teachers (Professors, Readers, Lecturers) and others interested in education.
University receives grants from Central Government, UGC, donors, tuition fees; no contribution of capital as such in imparting education.

legal_issues.text: Whether the work carried on by the University of Delhi (imparting education) is an 'industry' under s.2(j) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Whether applications under s.33C(2) are competent if not an industry.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant No.1 not an employer under s.2(g), work not an industry under s.2(j), applications under s.33C(2) incompetent.
Policy of Act leaves education and educational institutions out of purview; definition of industry should not be given widest literal meaning.

respondent_arguments.text: S.2(j) defines industry in words of widest amplitude; educational work is industry as it renders service to community with cooperation of employees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha (1960) 2 SCR 866

court_reasoning.text: Teachers not workmen under s.2(s); education primarily carried on with assistance of teachers, their exclusion significant; cannot treat education as industry for benefit of minor subordinate staff.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reading ss.2(g), 2(j), 2(s) together, educational work not industry.

court_reasoning.text: Education's purpose (building personality - physical, intellectual, moral, emotional) incongruous with trade/business; mission/vocation, not profession/trade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinctive purpose makes it difficult to assimilate to s.2(j).

court_reasoning.text: University organization by teachers, no capital contribution; subordinate staff minor/insignificant in main activity of imparting education.
Distinguishes precedents: Hospital Mazdoor Sabha left question open; Nagpur Corp. not deciding pure educational institutions; Australian case definitions differ.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No binding precedent holds education as industry.

holdings.text: Work of education by University of Delhi not an industry under s.2(j); applications under s.33C(2) incompetent.
University and Miranda House not employers in relation to industry.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha
precedents_cited.relevance: Working principle for industry; expressly left open question of educational institutions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Pilibhit v. Lalit Hari Ayurvedic College Pharmacy Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Left open whether running educational institution is industry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Research distinct from purely educational institution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Its Employees
precedents_cited.relevance: Municipal education department; predominant activity test; question of pure educational institutions not decided.

precedents_cited.case_name: Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia v. State of Victoria
precedents_cited.relevance: Majority held state education not industry; minority (Isaacs J.) not accepted fully; definitions differ.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industry, employer, workman; basis for applications and retrenchment compensation; education not industry reading definitions together.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi University Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Establishes University organization consisting of officers and authorities (teachers etc.) for imparting education.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; orders of Labour Court set aside; petitions under s.33C(2) dismissed as incompetent since University not carrying on industry.

key_quotes.text: "Reading ss. 2(g), 2(j) and 2(s) together, we are inclined to hold that the work of education carried on by educational institutions like the University of Delhi is not an industry within the meaning of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on why education not industry.

key_quotes.text: "Education in its true aspect is more a mission and a vocation rather than a profession or trade or business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains incongruity of treating education as industry.

key_quotes.text: "To speak of this educational process in terms of industry sounds so completely incongruous."
key_quotes.speaker: court
